gpt-message.content: You are an expert in hardware design with a deep understanding of Verilog RTL codes. Now I want to train a large language model for code comment generation tasks specifically focused on Verilog RTL codes. And I want you to help me process the raw data, transforming it into suitable formats that can serve as inputs and outputs for the model.

Name of the module and its functionality is as follows: 
1. Module name: There are two modules in this code snippet: "stimulus" and "Data_Memory".

   Explanation: 
   
   - The "stimulus" module serves as the testbench for the Data_Memory module that includes steps to write and read data from specific addresses in the module's register array. The output is displayed to monitor the correctness of the operations.
   
   - The "Data_Memory" module serves as a simple storage unit that stores and retrieves data on command. It uses a register array ("registers") as its main storage block. The module is capable of writing data to a register defined by 'dataInAdd' when 'regWrite' signal is active. Similarly, it reads data from a register defined by 'dataInAdd' and sets it on the output 'dataOut' when the 'regRead' signal is active. Both the operations are carried out on rising edge of the input clock.

Input and output ports and their explanation is as follows: 
For the "Data_Memory" module:

Input ports: dataInAdd, dataIn, regWrite, regRead, clock.

Explanation: 

- dataInAdd: This is a 16-bit input that serves as the address for the register where data is to be written or from where data is to be read.

- dataIn: This 16-bit input is the data to be written into the register specified by the dataInAdd when the write signal (regWrite) is active.

- regWrite: This is a single-bit input that serves as a write enable signal. If this signal is active (i.e., 1), the data from 'dataIn' input will be written into the register addressed by 'dataInAdd'.

- regRead: This is a single-bit input that serves as a read enable signal. If this signal is active (i.e., 1), the data from the register addressed by 'dataInAdd' will be set on the dataOut output.

- clock: This is the input clock signal which controls the pace of read/write operations. The read/write operations are performed at the rising edge of this clock.

Output ports: dataOut.

Explanation: 

- dataOut: This is a 16-bit output which reflects the data read from the register addressed by 'dataInAdd'. The value is available on this output whenever the 'regRead' signal is active.

Internal signals and their explanation is as follows: 
Internal signals: registers, Out.

Explanation: 

- registers: This is a memory array of 1024 16-bit registers (ranging from address 0 to 1023). This signal serves as the internal storage of the Data_Memory module. Each entry can be addressed using 'dataInAdd' for writing (when 'regWrite' is active) and reading (when 'regRead' is active) operations.

- Out: This is a 16-bit internal register that is used to hold the data read from the registers array (at the address specified by 'dataInAdd') when the 'regRead' is active. The value in Out is then assigned to 'dataOut' such that the data can be output from the module. 

This internal structure helps to accomplish the tasks of data storage and retrieval on command ('regWrite' and 'regRead' respectively) at a specific register address ('dataInAdd') in the Data_Memory module.
